notes:
Thanks to everyone who commented and shared the first fic! Decided to give this trope/idea some more screen time, since it's hilarious. "turn the beat around" is recommended, but not required to read this.

I'm planning on getting those next two chapters out ASAP. Hope you enjoy!

Thanks for all the awesome comments y'all! I appreciate them so much.

Here's the next chapter. Third part is written but needs a little editing love :) hoping to get that out ASAP.

For this next part, I think it's 100 times funnier if you remember that:
a) the boys are trying to protect Batman himself from death threats & kidnapping attempts, and are really only there for plausible deniability
b) Clark is absolutely furious with Bruce's lack of security and can't do shit about it, because Superman doesn't know Bruce Wayne, and Bruce wants to keep it that way
c) only Bruce and Clark know this

Last chapter! Thanks for sticking with it, folks. Hoping to maybe do more with this 'verse soon.

Another fun reminder:
a) Clark can hear everything they're saying outside the massage room
b) Bruce can't
c) none of what they said really registers with him until he's home later

(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)

That’s all for now!

text:
“So,” Wayne said, wincing as Bill tightened the cuffs around his wrists, “No zip ties today?”
“Yeah,” Jerry had already apologized three times for the metal handcuffs, and would likely continue for the duration of this kidnapping, “Client was real specific. Sorry, Mr. Wayne.”
He’d even blindfolded Wayne before he’d cuffed him this time, knowing that one look of pain in those blue eyes would have been their undoing. 
“Any discomfort?” Bill asked, manipulating the cuffs gently. He’d spent hours the previous day taping up the insides of the cuffs with soft tape, trying to blunt the edges as much as possible. 
The new kid was sweet. And Jerry couldn’t really blame him. 
“Usually, with handcuffs, that’s the idea,” Wayne said salaciously, wiggling his eyebrows behind the blindfold. 
Jerry groaned, holding up a finger only Bill could see. “What did I say about  Fifty Shades of Grey jokes?”
Wayne’s shoulders drooped. “That they’re culturally outdated?”
“They’re  inappropriate,” Jerry said, but the words had little bite to them. He nodded at Bill, who was blushing a bright red, “Look, you’re corrupting poor Bill.”
Wayne turned dutifully toward Bill, frowning into the blindfold. “I apologize, Bill. I didn’t mean to make you feel uncomfortable.”
Bill shot Jerry a dirty look, tapping Wayne’s shoulder in reassurance. “Don’t worry about it, Mr. Wayne. I’m not uncomfortable.”
“Good,” Wayne said, genuinely serious, “The power imbalances in a kidnapping really sneak up on me sometimes, you know?”
“Yeah,” Jerry said, signing at Bill to start clearing their way to the van. Luckily, they’d managed to nab Wayne in between his yoga and “flow” classes -- whatever the hell that was -- and they weren’t far. “Let’s go.”
Wayne greeted all the boys as he clambered into the van, waving his cuffed hands in the direction of their voices. Everyone immediately perked up, helping the billionaire sit down and asking him excited questions about his day. 
It had been almost two months since his last kidnapping, and Jerry could tell they’d been missing the man. He settled in behind Craig’s seat, tapping it twice to let him know they were clear. 
“Safehouse,” he said. Craig nodded, turning over the engine. “You got the food, right?”
“The gluten free pasta?” Craig clarified, cranking the wheel and steering them out of the parking lot. “Yeah. Shit was like twenty fuckin’ bucks.”
Jerry caught his eyes in the mirror in warning. Craig shrugged, looking back at the road. 
“--and then, well, I guess her whole class was mostly Shavasana?” Wayne was saying to Bill, Dillon and Jimmy, who looked enraptured, “And we all paid for a flow class, so everyone was just  baffled.” 
“Did people leave?” Dillon asked, scandalized, “I would have.”
Dillon wouldn’t know a yoga pose if it hit him over the head, but Jerry relented, staying silent. 
“That’s the crazy thing,” Wayne continued, oblivious to the captive audience he’d created. Even Craig was listening. “Once we laid there for about twenty minutes, I swear something in my back cracked. She said it was my chakra releasing, but I’m pretty sure it was just my slipped disc finally settling back into place.”
Jimmy looked more than a little mischievous, leaning forward on his heels. “Hey, Jerry’s back bugs him sometimes. Maybe we could all try it out back at the house?”
Jerry shot him a dirty look, too. Wayne, again oblivious to the exchange over his head, perked up even further. 
“I'd love to,” he smiled, turning toward Jerry with unerring ease, “You won’t regret it! I promise. I might even have some essential oil in my bag, if you grabbed it.”
Jerry looked at Bill, who nodded, holding up the small backpack Wayne had with him in the parking lot. 
“We did.”
 “Amazing,” Wayne said, and Jerry couldn’t help but smile along with him. “Have you ever heard of mindfulness?”
Two hours of measured breathing, stretching, and lying flat on the cold ass ground of the safehouse later, Jerry was ever so slightly starting to see the appeal of yoga. 
Next to him, Craig was snoring in corpse pose -- a term they’d been delighted to learn -- while the rest of the boys were somewhere between awake and asleep around the room, trying to follow Wayne’s instructions.
Wayne had walked them through a variety of basic forms, using his bound hands to carefully rub peppermint oil into their temples as they “meditated.” Now, he was seated at the “front” of the room, legs folded underneath him as he drew their session to an end. 
“--and we come back to our bodies slowly, feeling the breath in our lungs expand and contract…”
Jerry elbowed Craig in the ribs, waking him. The driver sent him a glare before lifting his head, spotting Wayne and then settling back down. 
“--knowing that the day ahead of us has many trials, but that you are centered, that you are strong. That you are mindful.” Wayne said, ending his class with a nod of his head. “Thank you for joining me today.  Namaste.”
“Namaste.” the room chorused. As one, they sat up, joints creaking and muscles stretching. 
Jerry groaned in pure relief as his back didn’t ache on the way up, pressing his palms into his thighs. Wayne crawled to his side in an instant, eager. 
“Feeling better?”
“Yes,” Jerry admitted, getting an amused look from Craig for his trouble, “Thank you for teaching us. You didn’t have to do that.”
“What else were we going to do?” Wayne asked, one shoulder rising and falling. “Which reminds me. Do we need a proof of life photo? It’s been a few hours, hasn’t it?”
Jerry rubbed a hand across his face, blowing out a breath. “Yeah, I guess we do.”
“Good. We can talk in the other room.” Wayne said. Jerry raised an eyebrow, grabbing his elbow and leading him. 
Once they were out of earshot of the boys, he dropped the hand. Wayne knew the way by now. 
“What did you want to talk about?”
Wayne smiled -- too bright, too many teeth, too  pointed -- and Jerry felt his heart stutter.
They dropped Wayne off with little fanfare after the ransom was paid, depositing him in the parking lot they’d snatched him from as Craig made yet another terrible joke about roundtrip service. 
Back at the safehouse, the boys gathered slowly in the kitchen, waiting for instructions on their payouts. The gluten free pasta box sat abandoned on the table, unopened. 
“Hey! Boys!” Jerry shouted, defaulting to his military voice when everyone wasn’t immediately present, “School circle, kitchen. Now!”
His laggers appeared in the kitchen shortly, taking their seats. Jerry crossed his arms, leaning against the counter. 
“Quick update before I pass out the info,” he said, “We got offered a new job. It’s time sensitive, so we need to make a decision  today  if we wanna take it.”
Jimmy raised an eyebrow. Bill looked curious. Dillon was clearly distracted, looking out the tiny window and probably mooning over Wayne still. 
“What kind of job?” Craig asked, lips twitching, “Because I’m not doing kids again. That was so fucked up.”
The boys, as one, nodded.  No kids.  
“Not a nab,” Jerry clarified, “It’s legit. Contract security for an event.”
At the word  legit, the entire room cringed back in distaste. Jerry held up his hands, heading off the inevitable protests before they could start. 
“I know. I  know we said we weren’t doing any legit jobs. But this one is special.”
“Who’s the client?” Jimmy asked, perceptive as ever. Jerry fought to keep himself from smiling, lowering his hands. 
“Bruce Wayne.”
The protests were immediately replaced by enthusiastic acceptance. 
“Oh, why didn’t you fucking say so?” Jimmy said, shaking his head. “Yeah, I’m in.”
“Security for Wayne?” Dillon asked. At Jerry’s nod, he grinned. “I’m in.”
“Oh, I’m in. I’m so in.” Bill said, excited. “Do you think we get to see his fancy house?”
“No, it’s at some party downtown,” Jerry said, ignoring his dejected look and turning to Craig. “Well?”
The driver shrugged. “Protection for him?” he seemed to think about it, “Yeah, fuck it. I’m in.”
“Good,” Jerry said, pleased it’d been that easy. “Brush up on your hand to hand before tomorrow night,” he finished, uncrossing his arms and turning toward the door. 
“Hand to hand?” Dillon asked, baffled. Jerry paused in the doorway. 
“Wayne doesn’t want guns. And what the client wants, they get.” Jerry winked at Jimmy, who looked absolutely devastated by this revelation. “Checks are on the corkboard. See you boys tomorrow.”
The room exploded into discussion behind him. Jerry headed out the back door, smiling to himself. 
They showed up to the address Wayne sent just before 8 PM, parking quietly next to the loading dock behind the hotel’s event hall. 
Even if the job was legit, old habits died hard -- and Jerry caught both himself and Craig craning their necks looking for witnesses as they filed out of the van. 
They were sans guns, as requested. To compensate, every single man carried at least three knives, a holdout grenade, and several pairs of flexicuffs.
Jerry hadn’t questioned the extra gear, but his expression as they unloaded the van must have been obvious. 
“Wayne gets kidnapped a lot,” Craig said, matter of fact as he pulled out what looked like a portable command station, “Boys just wanted to be prepared.”
Jerry neglected to add that at least 50% of those kidnappings were theirs. That number was surprisingly low, considering how often they kidnapped Wayne. 
“Dillon wanted to bring a machete,” Jimmy added, grabbing a handle and helping Craig drop the crate on the asphalt, “But we figured it was a fancy party like you said, so he left it at the house.”
Dillon was keeping watch by the door, shoulders drooping in obvious disappointment. 
Jerry shook his head, counting his lucky stars they’d at least all worn black. Wayne hadn’t exactly given them a dress code, but black blended -- especially in a crowd. 
Large bladed weapons didn’t, however. 
“Earpieces.” he murmured when the gear was nestled against the far wall of the loading dock. Craig pulled out the case, distributing the ear tips among the boys, then the wrist mics. 
Bill looked excited as he put in his earpiece, turning to Dillon with a shit-eating grin. 
“Like the fuckin’ Secret Service, huh?”
Dillon shrugged, putting his own earpiece in. “Sure, Bill.”
Jimmy took his silently, glancing at Craig, who looked at Jerry. Jerry shrugged, feeling the awkward tension of the word  legit hanging over them like a shroud. 
“Craig and I are gonna prep with Wayne,” he announced, straightening the cuffs of his dress shirt, “Set up the tech and listen for your assignments. We’ll be back soon.”
He turned to leave, but the group didn’t disperse immediately. Locking eyes with Craig, Jerry paused, considering. 
“Wayne,” he sighed, like it was a curse. Maybe it was. “Wayne -- he’s a good guy, right? Always did right by us?”
The boys nodded, expressions serious. 
“So he asked us for a favor,” Jerry said, rubbing his hands together, “We’re gonna do this job, and it’s gonna be fucking airtight, okay? No fucking around. No falling asleep, no getting distracted.” He made eye contact with each and every man. “Am I clear?”
“Yes sir!” 
“Great,” Jerry said, clapping Craig on the back. “Let’s go.”
Wayne was, predictably, in the middle of something when they arrived at his suite. He met them at the door with his cellphone crammed between his ear and shoulder, gesturing wildly for them to come in. 
“--no, I don’t have a comment on that--” he said into the phone, mouthing  water?  at Jerry and Craig, who both shook their heads. He then gestured at the wet bar, mouthing something that looked like  vodka?  
Somewhat reluctantly, they both shook their heads again. 
“--she said  what? No, I wasn’t even in the country at the time, are you kidding me--”
The suite was beyond extravagant. Craig sat on the obnoxiously satin-y sofa first, glancing at Jerry as Wayne began making his own drink one-handed. 
“--well, I don’t know what to tell you, Clark, maybe you should vet your sources a little better--” Wayne put a hand over the receiver, looking at Jerry and Craig, “Are you  sure you don’t want anything? I have whiskey.”
“Probably shouldn’t drink on the job, sir,” Jerry said, speaking for both of them. Wayne grimaced, uncovering his phone and going back to his conversation. 
“Anyway, Clark, I have to go. Don’t call me again. I mean that. Bye!”
Wayne threw the cellphone across the room. Jerry frowned, not sure he’d seen the man end the call before he’d chucked the phone. 
“Wonderful,” he said, spinning around and clapping his hands together. “You’re on time. I’m late, so I’m rolling with it. How’s the schedule looking?”
Jerry felt his frown deepen, struggling to keep his expression neutral. “You uh…didn’t give us a schedule yet, sir.”
“Right,” Wayne said, pausing. He pushed a hand through his hair, ruining the style. There were dark circles under his eyes, half-concealed by what looked like makeup. “What  did I give you?”
“Time and location of event.” Jerry summarized, “That’s…about it. Sir.”
“Hm.”
Wayne turned around, suddenly remembering his half-poured drink. He snatched it off the wet bar, joining Craig on the couch. Jerry continued to stand, shifting awkwardly. 
“I didn’t mean to leave you in the dark,” he said, looking genuinely regretful, “Lots of moving pieces right now. You understand, of course.”
In a way, Jerry could. He nodded, trying to be encouraging. Having more than one line of thought at once was probably a lot for the poor man. 
“Tonight’s event is a…well, it’s boring charity nonsense,” Wayne waved a hand at the door, looking irritated at the general direction of the event hall, “Dinner, an auction, the usual. They’re giving me a ridiculous award for donating money I already promised I’d give them ten years ago. It’s meaningless, really.”
Jerry didn’t ask who  they were. If it was important, they’d find out. 
“But I have to give a speech,” Wayne said, taking a swig from his glass. He made a face, swallowing harshly. “And that speech has to happen no matter what, or they don’t get the money.”
It was Craig’s turn to frown. 
“I know, but it’s a condition of the trust,” Wayne said, sensing their apprehension and waving it away again with startling perceptiveness, “And the money goes where it’s needed. This year, it’s homeless youth shelters. Admirable, right?”
Craig and Jerry nodded. Yeah, that sounded fine. 
“So,” Wayne held up his glass, toasting them with a tired smile, “I hired you because I know you can get me on that stage by 10 PM.”
“Of course, sir.” Jerry said, exchanging a look with Craig. They could do that. Package ferrying was even simpler than security, really. 
“And because you had a pretty high chance of being the ones who were going to kidnap me and prevent my speech in the first place,” Wayne added, deceptively light, “Which -- no hard feelings. Money is money. I just figured you’d rather take mine, this time.”
Jerry’s eyes narrowed, a burst of protective anger flitting through him. “Doesn’t mean someone else won’t try.”

 Or wouldn’t have tried already, before we even showed up… 

“I know. But I trust you,” Wayne said. And  oh,  that expression nearly cracked Jerry’s heart -- wide-eyed naivete with an edge of fondness he knew was their fault. “You’re  good at what you do. And you won’t hurt me. Not without warning me first, at least.”
Jerry felt a wave of revulsion at the thought of actually harming Wayne. He glanced at Craig, who was clearly thinking along similar lines. 
“We’ll get you on that stage, sir. On  time,” he stressed, crossing his arms. “And intact.”
Wayne smiled up at him, full of sunshine and foolish trust. “Mostly intact, I hope.”
“Can’t account for papercuts,” Jerry bit back, grinning slightly. Craig raised an eyebrow in his peripheral vision, looking back and forth between the two of them. “Sir.”
Wayne’s smile widened, revealing a blinding flash of white teeth. 
“Then I put myself in your very capable hands…Sergeant?”
So he’d done his research. Jerry fought the urge to blush, nodding at the old title. 
“Sergeant works.”
Wayne opened his mouth to say something, only to be interrupted by a ringtone that sounded suspiciously like  Baby Shark. He put up a finger, standing up and walking toward the corner where he’d launched his cellphone earlier. 
“I really thought I threw it hard enough this time,” he muttered, accepting the call. “Clark? No, I don’t care what you heard -- because it’s not  relevant, okay? Leave me alone, I’m working, for christ’s sake--”
Jerry and Craig watched as Wayne threw the cellphone back into the corner, rejoining them on the couch. 
“If a ridiculous horse of a man shows up claiming to be from the  Daily Planet,” he said to them, “I do  not want to speak with him.”
“Sure,” Jerry said, agreeing easily.  No horse men. “Any other persons we should be aware of?”
Wayne cracked his knuckles, grinning at them. 
“You have a pen and paper?”
The boys joined them up in the suite a half hour later, dragging the crates of gear with them through the lavish halls. 
They’d already ran into one ragtag kidnapping group in the service elevator, apparently, and had escorted them out of the building under threat of grenade and several knives. 
Dillon and Bill couldn’t have been prouder. Jimmy was cool as always, letting them have their moment as they recounted the (slightly embellished) story to Wayne, Craig and Jerry excitedly, complete with reenactments. 
Wayne watched with rapt attention, applauding politely at the end. With a sigh Jerry almost didn’t catch, he turned back to their earlier conversation, beginning again.
“--So  that mafia isn’t really happy with me, but they’re in Metropolis tonight. Or at least I think they are--”
Jerry noted the fourth possible death threat down on his pad in as much detail as he could, struggling to follow Wayne’s train of thought without interrupting. 
“--and then Salvatore, you know how his men are. I bit one of them once when they tried to take me. I couldn’t help myself. He put his hand over my mouth and he didn’t even  flinch when I licked him, so of course I had to try--”
Craig waved the boys into the suite’s kitchen, clearly thrilled by this turn of story. He lounged on the satin couch, watching their conversation with a half-filled snifter of brandy. 
“--so, they could show up.” Wayne summarized, waving a hand, “Oh, and Lex Luthor might send me some of his awful gin, which might as well count as a death threat. Can’t believe he makes that himself.” Wayne cut off with a grimace, “He really shouldn’t.”
Jerry dutifully took notes, scribbling  Luthor -- gin??? check packages as Wayne trailed off. 
“Is that it?”
The previously abandoned and twice-thrown cell phone chimed again from the corner. Wayne sighed, not bothering to get up. 
“Did I mention the  Daily Planet reporter?” he asked. 
“The horse man,” Jerry said, somehow managing a straight face. 
“That’s him,” Wayne replied, putting his head in his hands as the phone kept ringing. “Can someone throw that out the window, please?”
Sweet, innocent Dillon stepped toward the double-paned windows, frowning as he put a hand up to the glass. “I don’t think these open this high up, Mr. Wayne sir.”
“The ice bucket, then.”
Eyes wide, Dillon carefully picked up the phone, took off the lid, and sat it in the half-full ice bucket. A second later, he replaced the lid, looking sheepish. 
Wayne moaned in ecstatic relief as the ringing died with a gurgle. 
“You’re my favorite, Dillon.”
Dillon blushed bright red, looking anywhere but at Wayne. “You’re uh, welcome, sir.”
“Time?” Jerry asked Craig. The driver glanced down at his watch. 
“One hour.” 
As if on command, the lights in the suite cut out, plunging them into near-darkness. 
The room went silent. There was a long pause. 
“...Well,  shit,” Jimmy said, apt as ever.

 Okay, first--second?--attempt of the night, Stay cool.  

Jerry cursed quietly under his breath, pulling out his knife and taser. He faced the suite entrance, holding one in either hand. 
 Fuck, fuck fucking fuck…  
“Think Salvatore’s guys had a 9 PM grab?” Craig joked, standing and unsheathing his knife next to him. “Shit, those guys are punctual for mobsters.”
“Get Wayne in the bedroom,” Jerry told Dillon and Bill over his shoulder, “Barricade the door. Jimmy, you’re with us.”
Wayne was shuffled unceremoniously into the bedroom. Jimmy took up a defensive position behind it, flanking Craig and Jerry, knives in either hand. 
“Could’ve used a gun right now,” the sharpshooter said mournfully, looking at his hands, “Salvatore’s guys definitely got nice rifles, sir.”
“I told you to brush up on your hand to hand,” Jerry muttered, but it was beside the point, now. “Try to keep it close quarters. This much furniture, they’ll have a hard time staying mobile. Use that against them.”
At thirty seconds on the dot, six men filtered into the room through the main door, guns aimed at the floor. Jerry signed quickly at Jimmy and Craig, lurching forward. 

 Go go go go gogogogogogo----- 

Jimmy’s knife went through the first goon’s eye, knocking him down with a horrible squelching sound. Jerry didn’t stop to watch, leaping over his body and pinning the second man in the shoulder with his knife, cursing when he felt body armor under his fingers. 
“Heads up!” he yelled out to Craig and Jimmy, pinning the man in between his elbow and slamming his head into the wall. “They got armor!”
Somebody knew Wayne would have protection. They’d dressed for it, even. 
Next to him, Craig brained his goon with the butt of his knife, grinning savagely at Jerry as the man collapsed. Three down, three to go. 
The other half of the insurgent party wasn’t nearly as confident as their leaders. Jerry, Jimmy and Craig took them down with minimal bloodshed, leaving them unconscious on the thick carpet. 
Jerry handed over his flexicuffs to the other two, letting them handle the restraints. Breathing heavily, he stumbled to the bedroom door, knocking their all clear code. 
A moment later, Wayne poked his head out, flanked by Bill and Dillon. 
“Are they alive?” he asked, spotting the blood on the carpet. Jerry nodded, then paused. 
“Jimmy?”
Jimmy spared a glance at his first victim, sprawled near the wet bar. “Yeah, he’ll live. Might lose the eye though.”
Wayne looked mildly nauseous at that announcement. Jerry made an executive decision, sliding his knife back into his belt. 
“Time to move. Location isn’t secure any more.” He turned to Wayne, watching in the corner of his eye as Jimmy and Bill grabbed the crate, “Do you have a backup?”
“Well,” Wayne said. 
The hotel spa was fairly secure, all things considered. It had one entrance and exit, no windows, and the faint smell of lavender permeating every surface. 
The woman behind the desk left with little urging, disengaging from the knife-wielding group with a sigh that spoke of true Gotham experience. She greeted Wayne on her way out, who seemed briefly thrilled to be remembered. 
Craig set them up in the massage room, glancing at his watch as he directed Jimmy and Bill into the corner. 
“Thirty minutes,” he told Jerry, grimacing. “What’s the extraction plan?”
“Up three flights and two hallways over,” Jerry said, having memorized the layout as they’d descended from the suite. “Should take less than a minute to get there if we hurry.”
“Sounds tight.”
Jerry grimaced. “Yeah...”
Wayne laid himself across one of the massage tables, beckoning Bill and Dillon to join him. At a sharp look from Jerry, they declined, standing watch on either side of the billionaire. 
Near the entrance, Jimmy clicked his tongue. 
“Got incoming, Sarge.”
Jerry sighed, waving Jimmy forward. “Bill, Dillon--”
“Got it, sir,” Dillon said, ushering Wayne off the bed and into the massage room corner. “Mr. Wayne, if you would just, uh, crouch here--”
“Bruce!”
Jerry raised his eyebrows as a ridiculously tall man entered the spa, pushing the doors back and heading toward them with single-minded intent. 
The man was unremarkable save for his bulk -- somewhere over six foot, dark hair, thick glasses, cheap suit. He had a press ID around his neck, the tag flopping limply as he walked toward them. 
Wayne let out a dramatic sigh, stepping out from behind Bill and Dillon with an eye roll that could have crippled empires. 
“Clark.”
Jerry winced internally.  This is the horse reporter, then,  he thought, readying himself for another fight.  
“Excuse me sir,” Craig said, putting a hand out with the kind of authority Jerry wished he could muster, “I’m going to have to ask you to leave.”
 Clark looked at Wayne over Craig’s hand, sparing Jerry a brief glance. 
“What the  hell are you doing?” he asked, then seemed to lose a little steam, clocking Jerry’s hand drifting closer to his belt. “Bruce…”
Wayne rolled his eyes a second time. “Breaking out the curse words, are we?”
Behind him, Bill made a face -- probably reacting to the casual use of the man’s name. 
“You stopped answering your phone,” Clark said, eyes flashing behind his thick glasses, “I was  worried. I heard--” he cut off, glancing at Jerry again. Nervous?  
“You  heard  lovely Dillon here depositing my phone in the ice bucket,” Wayne said, waving a hand over his shoulder at Dillon, who was blushing again, “Which should have been a clue that  I don’t want to talk to you right now.” 
Jerry was missing a lot of history here -- it was obvious. He shifted on the balls of his feet, feeling the muscles in his calves clench. Something wasn’t what it seemed here, but Wayne didn’t seem keen on elaborating for their benefit. 
“Don’t do this,” Clark said, looking at Wayne desperately, fists clenching at his sides, “I -- ”
“Hey,” Craig said, waving at the man, “Yoo hoo! Dipshit? He said he doesn’t wanna fuckin’ talk to you, man.”
“Yeah.” Bill said quietly. Jimmy and Dillon both nodded in agreement.
“Get outta here.”
“Yeah.”
But something in the man’s eyes must have moved Wayne, because he relented with a cut off sigh. He muttered something too quiet to catch, clearly directed at Clark. 
“Give us a moment?” he turned to Jerry, edging dangerously toward  puppy eyes, “Please?”
“You said he was a threat.” Jerry said. It wasn’t really a question. 
Wayne shook his head. 
“To my sanity, maybe.” the billionaire shrugged, “He won’t hurt me. I know he won’t.”

 God fucking… 

“Alright.” Jerry glanced at Craig, who mouthed  twenty minutes at him. “You can have the room. We’ll be right outside if you need us.”
Wayne smiled, the softest one he'd seen all night. “Of course, Sergeant.”
“You’ll shout if you need  anything, ” Jerry said, pointing at him, “Got me?”
“I--yes. Yes. Thank you.” 
With a strange kind of familiarity, Wayne snagged Clark by the collar and pulled him into the massage room, closing the door behind them. 
Jerry put his head in his hands, breathing out slowly through his nose. 
“Dillon, Jimmy, Bill. Go sweep the main hall. Set up after that between there and the spa,” he directed, turning to Craig. “Craig and I will stay here for the extraction.”
“Sir.”
There’d been yelling, at first -- plenty of it. But that had quickly devolved into…whatever was happening on the other side of the door. 
Jerry stood against the massage room entrance, crossing his arms in front of him and trying desperately to ignore his burning face. 
Across from him, Craig checked his watch, raising an eyebrow as a decidedly  un-muffled groan vibrated through the door. 

 “Clark--” 

The groan was followed by a series of unmistakable thumps, and what sounded like plastic hitting the floor. Jerry winced, embarrassment flooding through him. 
Craig caught his gaze, then shrugged. 
“Good for him, you know?” he said to Jerry, leaning back against the wall. “Guy was kinda hot under the glasses.”
 I can’t believe I’m doing this,  Jerry thought as the door bumped under his shoulders,  If anyone walks down here...  
“Time?” he asked, instead of laying into Craig for something out of their control. 
“Ten minutes until he’s needed,” Craig responded, tapping his earpiece, “Boys are sweeping the main hall right now. Said the event chairs were getting antsy for Wayne and wanted an update.”
Jerry sighed. “What did you tell them Wayne was doing?” he asked, already regretting the question. The smile he got was almost feral. 
“Last minute interview,” Craig said, devilishly amused, “Off the record, of course.”
There was another groan from the massage room. Jerry felt the flush in his cheeks rise even higher, wondering when he became such a prude. 
Maybe it was just Wayne. Despite flirting with every person he saw, and making some of the most salacious jokes Jerry had heard outside of the service, the billionaire seemed almost…innocent, somehow. 
Letting his charge get railed in the massage room of an abandoned spa while he kept watch was the last thing Jerry had expected. The jokes, yes -- but not the follow through. 
Craig was watching him like he knew exactly what Jerry was thinking. He probably did. Jerry flipped him off, feeling off-kilter. 
“Yeah, yeah,” the other man said, shaking his head, “But think about it this way: we can always shoot him later if he breaks Wayne’s heart.”
